children.name: to talk about other people’s private lives
gossip b2
children.definition: gossip to spend time talking without a serious purpose, usually about other people’s private lives or behaviour:bép xép, nhiều chuyện
examples: it’s best not to tell frank anything. you know how he gossips.
gossip about
those two old ladies sit there every day, gossiping about everyone in town.

children.name: talk u
children.definition: talk if you say that peopletalk, you mean that theytalkabout other people’s private lives and behaviour, usually in a disapproving way: bàn tán
examples: we mustn’t be seen together in public again. people are starting to talk.

children.name: talk about sb behind their back
children.definition: /ˌtɔːk əbaʊt (sb) bɪˌhaɪnd ðeəʳ ˈbæk/  to talk about someone when they are not present: nói sau lưng ai đó
examples: ▪ i hate people who talk about you behind your back and then pretend to be nice to you when they meet you.

children.name: tongues are wagging
children.definition: /ˌtʌŋz əʳ ˈwægɪŋ/ used for saying that many people are talking about someone’s private life in an unkind or disapproving way: buôn chuyện
examples: ▪ tongues are wagging about hollywood’s newest couple.
set tongues wagging là chủ đề để người khác buôn chuyện
cause people to start talking about you
▪ thurmond’s marriage so soon after his wife died set tongues wagging.

children.name: gossip b2
children.definition: gossip to spend time talking to sb, especially sb you are friendly with, about things that are not particularly serious or important: ngồi lê đôi mách, nói chuyện phiếm
examples: cocteau’s jazz club was the spot where artists gossiped and drank.
gossip with
i wasn’t doing anything important - just gossiping with a neighbour.

children.name: chatter x
children.definition: chatter to talk continuously for a long time about unimportant things - used especially in literature: nói nhảm, nói xàm
examples: the tiny gray-haired woman chattered continuously as she demonstrated how to make a tortilla.
chatter with
they poured out of the school chattering with their friends.
chatter about
michele sat there chattering about her minor ailments to anyone who would listen.
chatter away/oncontinuously
i could hear the boys chattering away in the other room.

children.name: natter x
children.definition: natter uk informal if two people natter, they talk continuously for a long time about unimportant things: nói ba hoa
examples: natter with
▪ i can’t stand about nattering all day with you
natter about
▪ keith and tom were nattering about cars and not doing a stroke of work.

children.name: pass the time of day x
children.definition: pass the time of day to have a short, friendly conversation about unimportant things with sb you know, especially when you meet them by chance: chào hỏi, nói chuyện sơ sơ
examples: i just thought i’d stop by and pass the time of day.
pass the time of day with
whenever we met in the street, mr. kelly would stop and pass the time of day with me.

children.name: shoot the breeze x
children.definition: shoot the breeze us informal to have an informal conversation about unimportant things: chém gió, “gió nhẹ”
examples: ▪ the men spent their evenings on the porch, shooting the breeze.
shoot the breeze with
▪ hemingway came into the bar almost every morning to read the papers, shoot the breeze with the regulars, and enjoy bracing double daiquiris.

children.name: talk a1
children.definition: talk to say sth to sb, or have a conversation: nói chuyện
examples: ▪ we sat around talking for hours.
▪ two friends talking on the phone
talk about
▪ they talked about their favourite pop stars.
talk to/talk withus
▪ danny was talking to a girl he’d just met at the bar.
▪ it’s been nice talking to you.
▪ i left mario talking with my mother.

children.name: speak a1
children.definition: speak/spiːk/  totalkto someone.speakis more formal thantalk: nói
examples: ▪ the brothers haven’t spoken since the funeral.
speak to
▪ there’s a man from the times on the phone who wants to speak to you.
▪ i spoke to a few people at the party who knew him.

children.name: say sth a1
children.definition: say something/ˈseɪ sʌmθɪŋ/  nói gì đó
examples: ▪ did you say something? sorry - i wasn’t listening.
▪ no one said anything.
▪ the older woman said something in spanish.
say something about
▪ i can remember him saying something about his mother being ill.
say something to
▪ pradeep could hear her saying something to the nurse.

children.name: chat a2
children.definition: chat/tʃæt/  especially british to talk in a friendly and informal way, especially about things that are not very important: trò chuyện, nói chuyện phiếm
examples: ▪ the girls were sitting on the steps, chatting.
chat about
▪ we drank our coffee and chatted about our experiences.
chat with/to
▪ harry chatted to a couple of australian tourists as we waited for the show to begin.

children.name: have a conversation a1
children.definition: have a conversation/hæv ə ˌkɒnvəʳˈseɪʃənǁ-ˌkɑːn-/  to talk to someone for a period of time: có một cuộc nói chuyện
examples: ▪ could we just sit down and have a normal conversation without shouting?
have a conversation about có một cuộc nói chuyện về
▪ we were sitting around the kitchen table having a conversation about food and restaurants.

children.name: be in conversation a1
children.definition: be in conversation/biː ɪn ˌkɒnvəʳˈseɪʃənǁ-ˌkɑːn-/  to be having a conversation, especially one that takes all your attention: ở trong cuộc nói chuyện, nói chuyện
examples: be in conversation with
▪ when i arrived, diana was already in animated conversation with mr summers.
be deep in conversationso that you do not notice what is happening around you
▪ the two men were deep in conversation as they walked up the path.

children.name: make conversation/make small talk
children.definition: /ˌmeɪk kɒnvəʳˈseɪʃənǁ-kɑːn-, meɪk ˈsmɔːl tɔːk/  to make an effort to have a conversation with sb, just in order to seem friendly or polite: nói chuyện xã giao
examples: ▪ i tried to make small talk, but darden wasn’t interested.
▪ ‘why did you tell her that?’ ‘i was just making conversation.’
make polite conversation nói chuyện xã giao lịch sự
▪ sheila was sitting next to the boss’s wife and felt obliged to make polite conversation.

children.name: visit x
children.definition: visit us informal to talk in a relaxed way to sb you know well: thăm hỏi
examples: ▪ mom and aunt jo were sitting drinking coffee and visiting.
visit with
▪ i don’t see him that often, but i like to go and visit with him when i can.

children.name: converse x
children.definition: converse formal to have a conversation: trò chuyện, nói chuyện
examples: we met once and conversed briefly. that was the extent of our acquaintance.
converse with
the conference gave me an opportunity to meet and converse with vips in relaxed surroundings.

children.name: talk b2
children.definition: talk to discuss sth serious or important with sb :
examples: joe, we need to talk.
is there somewhere we can talk in private?
talk about
we’ve been talking about getting married.
talk to/ withus
you should talk to a lawyer.
parents should talk with their children about drug abuse.
gerry wants to talk to his girlfriend before he makes a decision.
it’s important to talk with your kids about drugs, alcohol, and sex.
talk sport/politics/business etcc1
‘let’s not talk politics now,’ said hugh impatiently.
whenever they're together, they talk politics.
registerin written english, people usually say that they are going todiscuss,deal with, oraddressa subject rather thantalk aboutit:
in this essay i willdiscussthe problem of over-population.

children.name: speak a1
children.definition: speak to talk to sb about sth serious or official.speakis a little more formal thantalk. you often use it when saying that you willspeakto sb in order to try to get something done: nói chuyện với
examples: speak to/ speak withus
maybe it’s time for you to speak to a lawyer.
the woman had come all the way from denver to speak with the president.
speak to/with sb about
i intend to speak to the manager about the way i have been treated.
have you spoken with michael about the scheduling conflict?

children.name: have a talk b1
children.definition: have a talk/ˌhæv ə ˈtɔːk/  to talk to someone seriously about something you have planned to discuss, especially about a problem or future plans: thảo luận, bàn luận, nói chuyện
examples: ▪ don and i had a long talk, and i think we understand each other better now.
have a talk about
▪ i think it’s time we had a talk about your future here in the company.
have a talk with
▪ if this behavior continues, i’m going to have to have a little talk with her
.▪ someone should have a serious talk with lucy about the amount of alcohol she drinks.

children.name: have a conversation a1
children.definition: have a conversation to talk to someone for a period of time about a serious subject: có cuộc trò chyện
examples: ▪ the two leaders had a brief conversation yesterday.
have a conversation with
▪ i’ve had conversations with several employers who say there are not enough qualified people to fill the jobs they have.
have a conversation about
▪ we need to have a conversation with our lawyers about the will.

children.name: have a word b2
children.definition: have a wordespecially spokento talk to sb quickly, and usually privately, about sth serious:
examples: could i have a word?
have a word with
i’ll have a word with him and see if he’ll help.
his attitude got so bad his manager was forced to have a word with him.
i’d like (to have) a word with you
i’d like a word with you in private.
have a quick/brief word
i was hoping to have a quick word with you.
have/exchange a few words
could i have a few words with you?
want a wordspokento want to talk to sb, especially in order to criticize them
want a word with
wait a minute! i want a word with you!

children.name: have a heart-to-heart x
children.definition: have a heart-to-heart talk/a heart-to-heart to have a private conversation in which two people both say honestly and sincerely what they feel about sth personal: có cuộc trao đổi thẳng thắn, chân thành
examples: don’t go in there right now - i think dean and carlo are having a heart-to-heart.
have a heart-to-heart talk/ a heart-to-heart with
if you think your boss doesn’t like you, have a heart-to-heart talk with her.

children.name: talk shop x
children.definition: talk shop if two or more people who do the same work talk shop, they have a conversation about their work on a social occasion: nói chuyện làm ăn, bàn công việc
examples: i don’t want to go out to dinner with him and his lawyer friends - all they ever do is talk shop.

children.name: to tell sb what you are feeling
get sth off your chest c2
children.definition: get sth off your chest/ˌget something ɒf jɔːʳ ˈtʃest/  to tell someone about something that has been worrying you or annoying you for a long time so that you feel better afterwards: giãi bày, nói hết nỗi lòng
examples: ▪ i feel so much better now that i’ve got that off my chest
.▪ writing to you is a good way to get things off my chest.

children.name: confide in x
children.definition: confide insb to tell sb about sth very private or secret, especially a personal problem, because you feel that you can trust them: tâm sự
examples: ▪ he was a good listener and elinor found it easy to confide in him.
confide in sb about
▪ he wanted desperately to confide in someone about his feelings of failure.
confide in sb that
▪ harriet confided in me that she and mark were considering divorce.

children.name: pour out your heart x
children.definition: pour out your heart/soul/ˌpɔːr aʊt jɔːʳ ˈhɑːʳt, ˈsəʊl/  to tell someone everything about some strong emotions that you are feeling, especially feelings of unhappiness: nói ra hết những gì trong lòng
examples: ▪ suddenly, jason burst into tears and poured out his heart, telling his mother all about everything.
pour out your heart/soul to nói ra hết những gì trong lòng với
▪ i had no idea kay was so unhappy until she poured out her soul to me last night.
